facts.text: On April 11, 1968 Ram Kumar, his brother Shiv Kumar, their mother and the appellant left Kanpur for Moradnagar.
On April 15, 1968 Ram Kumar, Shiv Kumar and the appellant left Moradnagar for Delhi to purchase a secondhand motor-cycle. Shiv Kumar went back to Moradnagar.
At about 7-15 p.m. on April 15, 1968 Ram Kumar and the appellant booked Room No. 2 at Hindustan Hotel, Ballimaran, Delhi, signing names Nasim Mahazroo and Ram Kumar with Kanpur address.
On April 16, 1968 Ram Kumar and appellant were together searching for a motor-cycle and met Abdul Hafeez, Babu Khan and Om Prakash.
On morning of April 17, 1968 Ram Kumar and appellant agreed to purchase motor-cycle from Babu Khan and Om Prakash for Rs. 1000/-. Ram Kumar paid Rs. 251/- advance. Sellers to deliver in evening.

At about 6 p.m. on April 17, 1968 Babu Khan and Om Prakash went to hotel with motor-cycle. Ram Kumar short of Rs. 300-400, sent appellant to get money from Ustad. They waited till 9-30 p.m., appellant did not return, they left.
At about 12-30 a.m. on night between April 17-18, 1968 Lal Chand (P.W.1) saw Ram Kumar and appellant going to their hotel room.
At about 10 a.m. on April 18, 1968 Lal Chand and Tek Chand (P.W.2) saw appellant locking Room No. 2 and leaving hotel.

On April 20, 1968 foul smell in hotel, lock broken, dead body of Ram Kumar found with two stab injuries (one near right eye brow, one near right ear) and nine contused lacerated wounds on scalp, brain deep. Stab by pointed sharp-edged weapon, others by hard blunt substance.
Lal Chand lodged FIR on April 20, 1968 at Lahori Gate PS mentioning occupation of room by Nasim and Ram Kumar, seeing them enter at 12-30 a.m. 17-18th, Nasim locking at 10 a.m. 18th, body found.
Appellant arrested May 4, 1968 at Gaya, Bihar in sister's house. Search recovered attache case with clothes, spanner set, allenkey set, connecting rod.
Deceased had about Rs. 700/- for motorcycle purchase.

Appellant admitted friendly terms with Ram Kumar, trip to Delhi for motorcycle, deal with Babu Khan/Om Prakash, Rs. 25/- advance (text says Rs.25/- in admission, Rs.251/- earlier), sent to get money from Ustad, sellers left before he reached.

Appellant's version: Could not get money, reached hotel 9 p.m. 17th, told Ram Kumar would go to Kanpur, left by 9-45 p.m. train, reached Kanpur 6 a.m. 18th, got Rs.450/- from Rafi on 19th, arrived Delhi evening 20th, heard rumors of murder implicating him, fled to Gaya out of fear. Denied recovery of articles.

Appellant went to Kanpur on 18th, stayed Himachal Hotel in assumed name S.N. Gander from 5-30 p.m. 18th to 4 p.m. 19th, got new terylene clothes stitched paying Rs.60/- tailoring to Chhedi Lal (Yasin Tailors) around 2 p.m. 18th or between 12 noon-8 p.m.
Connecting rod from sister's house had human blood stains.
Appellant in poor financial circumstances generally.
Additional Sessions Judge convicted under s.302 IPC, death sentence. Delhi HC confirmed conviction, reduced to life imprisonment on 23.10.1969.

legal_issues.text: Whether the circumstances established by prosecution are fully consistent with the guilt of the appellant and inconsistent with his innocence in the murder of Ram Kumar under s.302 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Lal Chand may have mistaken identity of companion of deceased at 12-30 a.m.
Appellant left Delhi at 9-45 p.m. 17th by train to Kanpur, could not have locked room at 10 a.m. 18th; supported by Chhedi Lal evidence of cloth delivery around 2 p.m. 18th in Kanpur.
Two different weapons used (stab and blunt), suggests at least two persons committed murder, appellant not sole perpetrator.
No incriminating articles recovered; panch witnesses hostile.

respondent_arguments.text: Circumstances: Arrival together 15th, booked room, together 16-17th, deal for motorcycle Rs.1000/-, advance Rs.251/-, short money, appellant sent for money, seen entering room 12-30 a.m. 17-18th, appellant locked room 10 a.m. 18th, body found 20th, Rs.700/- missing, appellant extravagant in Kanpur (new clothes Rs.60/-, false name hotel), fled to Gaya, blood-stained connecting rod recovered.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Circumstantial evidence rules: circumstances proved by cogent evidence, consistent only with guilt when taken together.

court_reasoning.text: Circumstantial evidence must be proved fully, consistent only with guilt, totality considered, not isolated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Circumstances jointly form chain proving guilt.

court_reasoning.text: Lal Chand's evidence reliable: hotel proprietor, no motive to falsely implicate, mentioned specifically in FIR before any clue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant and deceased entered room together at 12-30 a.m.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence of locking room at 10 a.m. 18th reliable, in FIR, Chhedi Lal evidence unreliable (vague time).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant locked room morning after, left.

court_reasoning.text: These two circumstances (entry together midnight, locking morning) plus missing money, extravagance in Kanpur (new clothes despite poor means, false name), irrational flight explanation, blood-stained rod sufficient to prove guilt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conduct post-arrival in Kanpur valuable link.

court_reasoning.text: Two weapons but appellant key participant even if others involved.
Recovery proved despite hostile panchas related to appellant.

holdings.text: Circumstances prove appellant guilty of murder under s.302 IPC beyond reasonable doubt.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed, High Court judgment confirming conviction under s.302 IPC and sentence of life imprisonment affirmed.

key_quotes.text: The circumstances have to be established by the prosecution by clear and cogent evidence and those circumstances must be inconsistent with the innocence of the accused.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is only when the various circumstances are considered jointly that it becomes possible to understand and appreciate their true effect.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: These two circumstances are by themselves sufficient to determine the guilt of the appellant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Refers to seeing entry and locking room.
